Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS: Unlocking the black box of feather louse diversity, a comprehensive revision of the hyper-diverse genus Brueelia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lice are parasites of birds and mammals that spend their entire life cycle on the body of the host. Their close association with the host has resulted in pronounced host specificity and cospeciation in some groups. Indeed, lice are a model system used in the development of analytical methods for assessing patterns and rates of cospeciation, as well as investigations into ecological factors governing speciation. In stark contrast to other louse systems, the lice in genus Brueelia appear to show a lack of cospeciation despite a high degree of host specificity. Unfortunately, the use of Brueelia as a model is hampered by poor taxonomy. The PIs will revise the taxonomy of Brueelia, reconstruct its evolutionary history, and investigate the relative importance of co-speciation, host-switching, and host biogeography in the evolution of this hyper-diverse genus.

Data, species keys, and results from the proposed project will be disseminated in scientific publications and websites. The PIs will host a workshop on the use of interactive keys, molecular, morphological and bibliographic databases at the "International Congress on Phthiraptera", which they will co-host in Utah in 2014. The PIs will work in collaboration with the Utah Museum of Natural History to produce a "Teaching Toolbox" that uses parasites to address key biological topics. The toolbox will be deposited at the Utah Museum of Natural History and made freely available to teachers across the state of Utah.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: One of the largest, but most poorly understood, groups of parasitic lice is the Brueelia -complex. These lice vary enormously in shape, color, dispersal ecology, and host specificity. A thorough understanding of macroevolutionary patterns in this complex promises to illuminate the ecological and evolutionary forces influencing diversification of lice in general. However, early taxonomic revisions of this group were confounded by extreme morphological variation, convergent evolution, and periodic movement of lice between unrelated hosts. The overriding goal of this project was to lay a solid phylogenetic foundation on which future studies can be built. Using a molecular approach we sequenced nuclear and mitochondrial genes and reconstructed the largest phylogenetic tree within the order Phthiraptera. The resulting, well supported, tree indicated that Brueelia, as then recognized, was paraphyletic. Moreover, despite the size of the tree (>300 taxa), only 22% of specimens could be assigned to formally described species, representing less than 15% of all known species in the Brueelia-complex. The remaining 78% included new species that could not be placed without a thorough taxonomic revision of the group. We revised the entire complex, based on morphologically distinct groups that were also supported by molecular data. The resulting monographic revision (in press), describes 22 new genera, 36 new species, and 23 synonymous species. It includes a key to all of the genera, which are fully described and illustrated (with over 500 figures). Additional manuscripts describing 45 new species will be submitted in the next year.

Broader Impacts: Teaching Toolbox - In association with the Utah Museum of Natural History (UMNH) we developed a “Parasite Toolbox.” The UMNH’s Teaching Toolbox program generates portable labs that encourage inquiry-based learning by providing specimens, lesson plans, activities, books and related teaching materials. Toolboxes are available to any teacher in the state of Utah for free, and in perpetuity. The Parasite Toolbox targets K-8th grades, and includes a role-playing module where students dress up as field biologists and go on an "expedition", during which they discover, dissect, and identify parasites. These young biologists are guided through the taxonomic process as they measure, illustrate, describe, and name their own mock parasite species. To launch the Parasite Toolbox, PI-Bush led educator workshops and in-class demonstrations in local K-8 classrooms.   Since 2013, the Parasite Toolbox has been used by 65 teachers with 1800 students.  Training – DEB-1050706 has also supported the training of two postdoctoral researchers, two graduate students, and five undergraduate students, including one Latino student.
